title.narrative: 4.4 NUTRITION CARE SMAM

description.narrative: Output 4.4: By 2018, children under five and pregnant and lactating women have access to and utilize quality preventive and treatment services against severe acute malnutrition, which contributes to Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 4: Children under 5, pregnant and lactating women, particularly among the most vulnerable, have access to and make greater use of quality promotional, preventive and curative services for the prevention of chronic malnutrition, management of acute malnutrition and reduction of micronutrient deficiencies.

participating-org.narrative: DREP DOSSO DREP MINISTERE DE LENSEIGNEMENT PRIMAIRE

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 4.4: By 2018, children under five and pregnant and lactating women have access to and utilize quality preventive andtreatment services against severe acute malnutrition

description.narrative: In 2018, integrated management of severe acute malnutrition continued to be provided nationwide through the health system and treated 354,008 children (93% of the national target, as of end of November data). Performance indicators met minimum standards with cure, death and defaulter rates of 89.2%, 1.6% and 6.6% respectively. | Status:Met | As-of Date:30/01/2019

title.narrative: The seasonal malaria chemoprevention campaign and incorporation of Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) screening for malnutrition is continued.
% of children under five years of age suffering from SAM treated successfully in health facilities each year
% of health districts that systematically conduct at least two rounds of screening for acute malnutrition during the
Percentage of health and nutrition workers trained on management of SAM as per national standards
Percentage of health facilities reaching more than 75% of cure rate for the management of SAM
Percentage of health facilities with zero stock out of supplies for the management of SAM as per national standards
% of children under five years of age suffering from SAM admitted into the CMAM programme each year
Existence of a pre-service training curriculum for community-based/integrated management of SAM for health and nutrition workers
Existence of national protocols for the management of SAM based on WHO standards
